Summary: The proposal aims to develop a unified multimodal representation learning framework that bridges vision, audio, and language modalities using a modality-agnostic backbone with dynamic parameterization, cross-modal contrastive learning, and a latent completion mechanism for sparse data. The experimental plan includes validation of the backbone, cross-modal alignment tests, sparse data handling assessment, efficiency benchmarking, and ablation studies.
Strengths: Innovative hypothesis combining dynamic parameterization, contrastive learning, and latent completion.
Comprehensive experimental plan covering multiple aspects of the proposed method.
Weaknesses: Feasibility concerns regarding dynamic parameterization and latent completion mechanisms.
Lack of depth in addressing computational overhead and scalability.
Experimental plan could benefit from more rigorous baselines and deeper ablation studies.
Questions: How will the dynamic parameterization handle the vastly different structural characteristics of vision, audio, and language modalities?
What are the expected computational costs of the proposed diffusion model for latent completion, and how will scalability be ensured?
Are there any theoretical guarantees or bounds on the performance of the shared latent space across modalities?
Limitations: Potential high computational overhead due to dynamic parameterization and diffusion models.
Risk of overfitting in the shared latent space due to the complexity of aligning multiple modalities.
Limited discussion on how the model will handle real-world noisy or misaligned multimodal data.
